data.title: Pension Funds
data.text:
The Almenni Pension Fund is open to those who can choose their own pension fund. In addition, it is an occupational pension fund for five occupations: architects, tour guides, doctors, technologists and musicians. One third of compulsory premiums go into an inheritable private asset account at Almenni.

Birta Pension Fund (Birta lífeyrissjóður) is open to all not having compulsory membership in another pension fund.

The fund is a traditional occupational fund, where members of specified occupations have compulsory membership.

Brú Pension Fund (Brú lífeyrissjóður) of municipal employees is for people working for municipalities and are members of the Association of Academics (BHM), the Federation of State and Municipal Employees (BSRB), and the Icelandic Teachers' Union (KÍ). The fund has three mutual insurance divisions, Division A, Division B and Division V (open to all). The fund also operates the Reykjavik Employees’ Pension Fund.

EFÍA is the pension fund of the Icelandic Air Line Pilots Association (IALP). The fund is open to all members of IALP. Arion Bank's Asset Management sees to the operations and asset management of the pension fund.

Festa Pension Fund came out of the merger of the pension funds of Sudurnes, South Iceland, and West Iceland. The region of the Festa Pension Fund’s operations is West Iceland, South Iceland, and Sudurnes. The fund is open to general wage earners and self-employed individuals who live in the fund’s region of operations.

The Free Pension Fund (Frjálsi lífeyrissjóðurinn) suits those who can choose which pension fund they pay premiums into and those who build up supplemental pension savings. The fund combines the options of mutual insurance and private savings and offers fund members the highest apportioning of premiums into private pension savings of all pensions.

Gildi is Iceland's third biggest pension fund. The fund operates both a statutory mutual insurance

division and a private savings department. Gildi resulted from the merger of Framsýn Pension Fund and Fishermen's Pension Fund and later merged with West Fjorders' Gildi Pension Fund. Eleven unions belong to the fund. However, everyone may pay into it.

The Icelandic Pension Fund is open to all those who may choose the pension fund into which they pay. The fund gives more possibilities to accumulate private savings than a traditional pension fund. The fund better suits both those paying compulsory premiums and those paying into supplementary pension savings. The fund has an operating agreement with Landsbanki

Bank Employees' Pension Fund is one of the oldest operating pension funds in the country. It was founded in 1929. The members of the fund are Landsbanki, the Central Bank of Iceland, Banks' Data Centre, the Confederation of Icelandic Bank and Finance Employees, and Valitor. The fund operates two divisions, the Proportional Division and the Age Division.

The Farmers' Pension Fund began operations on 1 January 1971. The fund is open to all members and is also the occupational fund for all farmers and their spouses running farms.

The Pension Fund of Rangá District Residents is a mutual insurance fund, founded 12 January 1971. The member associations are the South Iceland Labour Union (Vlfs), the Association of Industrial and Technology Industries (Fit), and SA-Business Iceland (Sa). Arion Bank's Asset Management sees to the operation and management of the fund’s assets. Its offices are at Sudurlandsvegur 3, 850 Hella.

The members of the fund are all employees of Akureyri Town and its institutions who were hired before 1 January 1999, the date when the fund was closed. Stapi Pension Fund sees to the operation of the Pension Fund of Employees of Akureyri Town, in accordance with an agreement between the funds involved.

The members of the Agricultural Bank of Iceland’s Employees’ Pension Fund are the employees of the Agricultural Bank of Iceland. The fund is a proportional fund and stopped accepting new members in 1998.

The Reykjavik Employees' Pension Fund is for Reykjavik's employees working for the city before 1998 when the fund stopped accepting new members. It has since been operating under Brú Pension Fund.

LSR is a labour union pension fund for public employees that ensures its members their extensive rights upon resignation or retirement from work, disability and death. LSR also sees to the administration of Pension Fund for Employees of the Fisheries Bank of Iceland.

LV - the Pension Fund of Commerce was founded in 1956. The fund is open to all wage earners working under an LV wage agreement and several other unions, those that can choose membership in a pension fund, as well as all self-employed individuals.

The Westman Islands Pension Fund has operated since 1970 and today operates a mandatory mutual insurance department and a private property department. The fund is for those belonging to unions related to it, but is open to everyone.
